Hi,

it turned out that I only needed offset information from
cdx files. Those java tools are quite grand for such task
and I managed to write a couple of Perl lines to count
file offsets => I can now read html, images etc. from 
uncompressed arc files. 

All well, but one has to be very careful when reading
binary data from arcs. Reading one blank or linefeed
too much corrupts an image, although does really nothing
to html or text file. 

Even a program which retrieves data from arcs may
add a linefeed to a wrong place. I supppose that 
the Danish tools are so tested that you
can fetch images from arcs and look at them

?kaisa?

> On Wed, 2004-04-07 at 12:57, kaisa_kaunonen wrote:
> > Hi, 
> > 
> > I collected a nice test archive of about 100000 docs with 
> > heritrix 0.6.0
> > I think it went well (I didn't yet try out very baaad web sites;)
> >  
> > Now I try to index the archive with nwatoolset. 
> > At this point it seems that cdx files are needed.
> > How do I generate them? 
> 
> To get away from the Alexa tools, which can be quite difficult to
> compile, we have developed some Java tools that are available at
> www.netarchive.dk.  They can make (unsorted) cdx files from
> (uncompressed) arc files[1], do binary searches and get entries out 
of
> arc files, and write new arc files.  They're not optimized for huge
> collections like the Alexa tools are, for instance can't handle
> multi-file cdx files yet, but we use them internally with success. 
> They're all under GPL, and improvements are welcome.
> 
> -Lars
> 
> [1] Actually, they do support compressed arc files, except they 
can't
> figure out the length of the compressed entry, so they can't scan
> through them.  There's ways to do that, but I at least prefer to 
just
> not compress the files.
